newsitem.title: UK: EMU expectations rise but UK bucks trend-JP Morgan.
newsitem.headline: EMU expectations rise but UK bucks trend-JP Morgan.

text.p: Market expectations of a broad-based start to European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) improved this week while Ireland lead the way and Britain bucked the trend, financial prices monitored by JP Morgan showed Friday.

JP Morgan's "EMU calculator" showed that optimism about starting EMU increased in all monitored countries this week. In Ireland, the assumed probability of a 1999 EMU start rose 12 percentage points to 75 percent in the past week.
Britain, however, swam against the tide with the probability assumed by the market that it will join Germany and France in EMU's first wave falling to 44 percent from 49 percent.

The so-called 'Club Med' countries all saw their chances increase. The probability assumed by the market that Spain, Italy and Portugal will join EMU in 1999 increasing to 80 percent, 62 percent, and 83 percent respectively.
The U.S. investment firm's calculator --which is derived from the interest rate swaps market -- showed the readings for France and Belgium remained at 100 percent.
JP Morgan points out there is a reasonable margin of error in overall probability levels of between three and five points.
The probabilities are derived from the actual swap spread, an in-house assumption of what the spread would be if EMU were not a factor, and the expected spread after EMU participation, which is zero.
